entry.title: Prince Ali expects sponsors to snub FIFA if Blatter stays
entry.summary:
FIFA presidential candidate Prince Ali bin al-Hussein believes the scandal-hit organization will struggle to replace sponsors and be hurt financially if Sepp Blatter remains in charge.

But Prince Ali of Jordan has used his FIFA manifesto, which was launched on Monday, to express concerns that corruption allegations around FIFA are putting off commercial backers.

"We should have a situation where sponsors are not only willing to come back but we should have sponsors fighting to sponsor FIFA," Prince Ali said in an interview with The Associated Press.

"FIFA is riding on the success of the World Cup," Prince Ali said from Cairo where he is campaigning at a Confederation of African Football meeting.

FIFA said in January it was in "advanced negotiations" with potential partners for the 2018 World Cup, but no information on new sponsors have been announced since then.

entry.title: EU parliament urges Blatter to quit FIFA immediately
entry.summary:
The European Parliament said Blatter's failure to depart immediately would block efforts to rid FIFA of rampant corruption.

The soap opera at FIFA took another turn when it announced that De Gregorio was leaving two days after making a joke at FIFA's expense on a Swiss chat show.

"The FIFA president, secretary-general and media director are sitting in a car. Who's driving. Answer? The police," De Gregorio said.

A FIFA statement gave no reason for De Gregorio leaving what had become an increasingly thankless job of defending FIFA during the scandal.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary:
GENEVA (AP) " FIFA's top spokesman left his job Thursday, hours after Sepp Blatter was urged to do the same by the European Parliament.

Schawinski closed the show by asking De Gregorio to tell his favorite joke about FIFA.

De Gregorio set up the punchline by saying the FIFA president, himself and secretary general Jerome Valcke were in a car, so who was driving?

FIFA announced the exit of De Gregorio in a terse statement that did not have comment from the president or his spokesman.

FIFA said De Gregorio "would be retained as a consultant until the end of the year."

entry.title: European lawmakers urge FIFA president Blatter to go now
entry.summary:
STRASBOURG, France (AP) - European lawmakers have urged FIFA President Sepp Blatter to step down immediately, and for an interim leader to be appointed.

FIFA is not obliged to heed the parliament and has previously dismissed calls for action made by lawmaker groups, including the Council of Europe.

entry.title: Analysis - FIFA to hold new election but concerns it under old rules
entry.summary:
LAUSANNE, Switzerland (Reuters) - FIFA began the process of finding a replacement for outgoing president Sepp Blatter on Wednesday with the same system which has caused problems in the past.

On Wednesday, Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General seized further data from FIFA as part of its probe.

entry.title: Football: Zico puts his name in the hat for Fifa President
entry.summary:
Former Brazil star Zico wants to run for the presidency of FIFA, even though he believes the odds are stacked against him being elected.

"I would like to confirm this decision about the possibility of being a candidate in the next FIFA election," Zico told a news conference in his native Rio de Janeiro.

FIFA said earlier Wednesday its executive committee would meet next month to choose an election date.

entry.title: New members of FIFA's scandal-hit executive committee
entry.summary:
The FIFA executive committee might have the worst reputation of any international sports body, still many candidates want to sit at the high table of soccer's world governing body, known as the Exco.

Two members of Asian royalty and a former Manchester United CEO are among nine men who will formally join the ExCo at the FIFA congress on Friday.

The ExCo, chaired by the FIFA president, now includes 24 elected men, one elected woman and two women co-opted on rolling one-year mandates.

By moving into FIFA, the 51-year-old sheikh fueled talk he wants to succeed Sepp Blatter, his longtime fellow IOC member.

David Gill and Wolfgang Niersbach have reputations as soccer men of integrity who won't just stay quiet to collect their annual $200,000 stipend from FIFA.

Two men had expressed ambition to succeed FIFA senior vice president Issa Hayatou of Cameroon as leader of African soccer.

Gill was Manchester United's CEO for 10 years, working closely with Alex Ferguson, and now has the FIFA vice presidency reserved for British federations.

entry.title: FIFA-financed movie nets only $900 in limited US release
entry.summary:
Made for about $30 million and largely bankrolled by FIFA to trumpet the soccer federation's 111-year history, "United Passions" had no expectations of drawing crowds.

But the minuscule result still was a striking repudiation of a high-priced FIFA puff piece starring Tim Roth as FIFA President Sepp Blatter, who announced last week that he will resign.

The film's U.S. release was planned months before a Justice Department investigation alleged rampant corruption throughout FIFA and indicted 14 FIFA officials and soccer marketing executives.

The movie, which also stars Gerard Depardieu as World Cup creator Jules Rimet and Sam Neill as former FIFA president Joao Havelange, gives a generally rosy view of the scandal-plagued FIFA.

entry.title: FIFA-financed movie nets only $900 in limited US release
Bach: FIFA must go through 'painful experience' to reform
entry.summary:
Bach gave his most extensive comments to date on the bribery allegations engulfing FIFA, a far-reaching scandal that led Sepp Blatter to resign as president last week pending new elections.

Bach said the size of the FIFA scandal was much bigger than the case that led to the ouster of 10 IOC members for accepting improper inducements during Salt Lake's winning bid for the 2002 Winter Games.

"We can only encourage FIFA to continue (with) the reforms which have been initiated, we cannot give detailed advice of what to do but we appreciate there is a readiness for reforms," he told a news conference.

"The structure of FIFA is very different from the IOC and the difference in the scope is huge. There is almost no comparison of what happened with Salt Lake City and what is now at stake with regards to FIFA," said Bach.

FIFA will let Europe bid for the 2026 World Cup despite comments by FIFA chief Sepp Blatter that it would be too soon after Russia hosts the 2018 tournament.

Instead, FIFA's executive committee on Saturday kept an existing rule blocking continents from hosting back-to-back World Cups - so Asia would be excluded in 2026, since Qatar is hosting the 2022 World Cup.

entry.title: Europe's rift with FIFA deepens with Blatter's re-election
entry.summary:
As Blatter delivered his triumphant address, UEFA President Michel Platini was behind him on the Zurich stage but was already plotting along with European colleagues on how to bring down a FIFA powerbase mired in accusations of corruption and cronyism.

Europe's best hope is that Blatter has been wounded by his failure to secure a commanding mandate and might be further undermined if ongoing criminal cases against FIFA officials uncover wrongdoing close to the presidency.

"I am proud that UEFA has defended and supported a movement for change at FIFA," Platini said.

Dutch federation president Michael van Praag, who had been running for FIFA presidency before withdrawing last week to back Prince Ali, said Blatter's re-election showed that "the majority of (FIFA's) congress don't want a change."

The latest battering to FIFA's credibility came when Swiss and U.S. criminal probes into corruption were disclosed two days before the presidential vote, with several leading officials arrested in Zurich.

entry.title: FIFA email connects Sepp Blatter to $10M, newspaper claims (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary:
South Africa's Sunday Times reported that the email from FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke to the South African government asks when the $10 million, characterized as a bribe by American investigators, will be transferred.

FIFA said in a statement to The Associated Press on Sunday that sending money to Warner was the idea of the South African government and Blatter was being updated by Mbeki in their discussions.

The DOJ said South Africa's $10 million was used to pay off Warner and Blazer four years after the vote and was channeled through FIFA to Warner and dressed up to look like legitimate funds for soccer development.

entry.title: Champions League Highlights Importance of Europe to FIFA
entry.summary:
As the powerbrokers of European soccer celebrated their championship weekend and some jokingly congratulated themselves for staying out of jail, many said that the next FIFA president needs to do a better job of listening to the continent that pays most of the bills.

"It is fundamental for those who are risking investing their money in professional football in Europe have the opportunities to design the rules and regulations. We deserve to be there (at FIFA) because of what we represent."

The other big question was who is best positioned to lead the world's biggest game out of this mess, with Sepp Blatter preparing to vacate a FIFA headquarters that has already been raided by Swiss police.

entry.title: Russia, Qatar World Cups could be taken away: report
entry.summary:
Domenico Scala told SonntagsZeitung that FIFA the two countries could lose the hosting rights should evidence emerge of bribery in the bidding process.

Scala had made similar comments in 2013 but events over the last two weeks, which included a dawn police raid in Zurich and the arrests of several FIFA officials on U.S. charges, have added urgency to his remarks.

"If a FIFA president does two or three cycles that is enough," Scala is quoted as saying.

entry.title: Disgraced FIFA president starts work on reforms amid crisis (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary:
''Working hard on reforms after meeting Audit & Compliance Committee Independent Chairman Scala,'' Blatter wrote, along with a link to a statement released by FIFA.

In his statement on Thursday, the first since calling for new elections to find a successor, Blatter said he met with FIFA audit panel chairman Domenico Scala ''to establish a framework for action and a timetable'' for his final months.

''I want a comprehensive program of reform and I am very aware that only the FIFA Congress can pass these reforms,'' Blatter said in the statement.

PARIS (AP) - Interpol added six men with ties to FIFA to its most wanted list on Wednesday, issuing an international alert for two former FIFA officials and four executives on charges including racketeering and corruption.

Two of the men, former FIFA vice president Jack Warner of Trinidad and former executive committee member Nicolas Leoz of Paraguay, have been arrested in their home counties.

entry.title: Sponsors say Blatter resignation one step in FIFA reform
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - For FIFA's top sponsors, the resignation of Sepp Blatter is just the first step in restoring the reputation of soccer's governing body and regaining the fans' trust following a corruption scandal.

Blatter resigned as FIFA president Tuesday, amid pressure from colleagues, sponsors, athletes and fans.

entry.title: Sponsors say Blatter resignation one step in FIFA reform
entry.summary:
Sponsors, including Coca-Cola and Visa, said they were examining their relationship with FIFA.

"The allegations of corruption and questionable ethics within FIFA have overshadowed the game and taken away from the sport, players and fans," McDonald's said.

"We're hopeful that the changes being implemented within FIFA will be a big first step in positively reforming the organization."

However, the Jordanian prince - a FIFA vice president - did not notify football's governing body of the attempt to corrupt the election or that Blatter's purported private information was apparently being touted.

On Friday, Blatter, who has been FIFA president since 1998, will face the first contested vote for the job since 2002.

entry.title: FIFA challenger says he was offered Blatter's financial info
entry.summary:
The challenger's campaign said Monday it was approached by an individual who offered details on Blatter's finances and claimed to be able to help deliver dozens of votes in the head-to-head contest for the FIFA presidency.

"The FIFA administration has not been informed of any such matter," FIFA said in a statement to The Associated Press.

Quest said the potentially illegal offers did not come from people claiming to work for any of FIFA's 209 member associations.

entry.title: Palestinians to push forth with bid to oust Israel from FIFA
entry.summary:
The head of the Palestine Football Association says he is pressing forth with his bid to oust Israel from FIFA despite efforts from its president to diffuse the crisis.

FIFA President Sepp Blatter was recently in the region on a self-described "mission of peace" to resolve tensions between the two sides.

Blatter opposes the suspension vote, saying Israel has not broken FIFA statutes in a political issue outside of soccer's control.

entry.title: Platini pledges support for Prince Ali in FIFA bid
entry.summary: "I have the deep conviction that Ali, who I have known personally for years, could be a great president for FIFA," he said.

entry.title: Platini: FIFA led by Blatter will always lack credibility
entry.summary: Platini, now 59, was a key campaigner helping Blatter become FIFA president in 1998 and then a long-time heir apparent.

entry.title: Platini: FIFA led by Blatter will always lack credibility
entry.summary:
Ahead of the FIFA presidential election on Friday, Platini said the 79-year-old Blatter had no grand plans for FIFA and it was "not credible" to claim he needed a fifth four-year term to complete an unfinished mission.

"No, he is simply scared of the future, as he has given his life to the institution, to the point where he now identifies himself fully with FIFA," Platini said.

"I understand the fear of that emptiness that he (Blatter) must have, it's natural. But if he really loves FIFA, he should have put its interests ahead of his own."

Though Platini said he likes Blatter on a personal level, his explicit criticism of the FIFA chief points to a deep rift between the two men.

He opted last August not to challenge Blatter in the election of 209 FIFA member federations and now supports the only opponent: FIFA vice president Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan.

"I am firmly convinced that Ali, whom I have known on a personal level for years, would make a great FIFA President. He has everything it takes," Platini said of the prince, praising his "great freedom of spirit and independence."

entry.title: Luis Figo quits FIFA race, blasts soccer's governing body
entry.summary:
The Portugal great and former FIFA world player of the year said in a statement sent to The Associated Press that he refuses to go along with an election process that is designed "for the delivery of absolute power to one man" - indicating Blatter, the current FIFA president.

"I have seen with my own eyes federation presidents who, after one day comparing FIFA leaders to the devil, then go on stage and compare those same people with Jesus Christ," Figo said.

He said FIFA was "living under a dictatorship" with Blatter, whose re-election is widely expected.

entry.title: Van Praag withdraws from FIFA presidential bid
entry.summary: "Michael van Praag decided to withdraw his candidacy to become the next FIFA president and to join forces with presidential candidate Prince Ali Al Hussein," said a statement published by his campaign organisers on Thursday.

entry.title: FIFA sets date for 2026 World Cup hosting bid rules
entry.summary:
GENEVA (AP) - A 2026 World Cup hosting contest which could include the United States and exclude Europe will take shape next week when FIFA agrees on campaign rules.

"It is more than an option," Blatter told reporters last week when asked if FIFA could tighten the continental rule.

Currently, the FIFA statutes only prevent confederations from hosting back-to-back World Cups.

entry.title: Ghana defender Jonathan Mensah banned 4 months by FIFA
entry.summary:
The Court of Arbitration for Sport said its appeal panel upheld Mensah's suspension imposed by FIFA last July in a case dating to 2011.

However, FIFA said Tuesday that Mensah - who played at the past two World Cup tournaments - is eligible to play for Ghana next month.

FIFA judged that Mensah was still contracted to Udinese when he joined French club Evian Thonon Gaillard four years ago claiming to be a free agent.

Under FIFA rules, Mensah will serve about one month of the ban until the French season ends.

entry.title: Arsenal's Zelalem cleared by FIFA to play for US

CHICAGO (AP) " Arsenal midfielder Gedion Zelalem has been cleared by FIFA to play for the United States and has been added to the roster for the Under-20 World Cup next month.

Zelalem obtained U.S. citizenship in December, and the USSF applied to FIFA to make him eligible for its national team system.

entry.title: Tahiti FA director Temarii banned for eight years by FIFA

entry.title: Former FIFA VP Temarii banned 8 years for taking money

Temarii, then the OFC president, was appealing a one-year suspension by FIFA which barred him from voting in the 2018 and 2022 contests.

Temarii's FIFA colleague, Amos Adamu of Nigeria, was also barred from the World Cup vote and served a three-year ban from football.

Four former FIFA executive committee officials also served bans in the case.

FIFA introduces more racism surveillance for World Cup
entry.summary:
LONDON (Reuters) - A new system of match observers monitoring incidents of racism and discrimination at 2018 World Cup qualifiers was announced by FIFA on Tuesday.

Any incidents of discrimination or racism will be reported to FIFA which has pledged to impose disciplinary sanctions on any countries involved.

Last month FIFA president Sepp Blatter said "a lot of work needs to be done" to wipe the scourge of racism and discrimination from Russian soccer and the game in general.

entry.title: FIFA observers to monitor racism at World Cup qualifiers

FIFA president Sepp Blatter said last month in Moscow there was still a "lot of work to be done" to fight racism in Russia.

"In my part of the world, and also many other parts of the world, people started to dislike FIFA ... That is what we need to change. And if Mr. Blatter stays for another four years, we will continue the exactly the same way."

Van Praag, who promised immediate transparency if he is elected president, also questioned the decision to spend $27 million on a movie about FIFA, starring Hollywood star Tim Roth as Blatter.

The PFA defied FIFA President Sepp Blatter's wishes by pushing for a vote of 209 member countries on May 29 in Zurich.

FIFA says Blatter met Israeli soccer leaders on Wednesday and told them "any member association that is fulfilling its statutory duties should not be suspended."

entry.title: Kingmaker Sheikh Ahmad to take first step towards FIFA throne
entry.summary:
The chances of any of them actually beating Blatter when FIFA's 209 members cast their votes in four weeks time are slim.

But the man being identified as the one to eventually take Blatter's crown is the highly influential political kingmaker Sheikh Ahmad Al-Fahad Al-Sabah of Kuwait, who will, almost certainly be elected to FIFA's executive committee on Thursday.

Now, with the backing of AFC president Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim Al Khalifa, Sheikh Ahmad, the honorary president of the Kuwait FA, is set to win one of the three Asian seats on the FIFA executive committee.

The Jordanian reformer, who has sat on the FIFA executive committee for the last four years as the Asian vice-president, will leave the executive unless he wins the presidential election.

His FIFA seat will be taken by AFC president Salman following a realignment of Asia's policies, and he is not standing for election as one of the three Asian FIFA executive committee members.

entry.title: Japan to host FIFA Club World Cup in 2015 and 2016

The FIFA Club World Cup features the champions of all six FIFA confederations -- Asia, Africa, CONCACAF, Europe, Oceania and South America.

JAKARTA (Reuters) - Indonesia's youth and sports ministry on Saturday suspended all activities of the local soccer association (PSSI), setting the stage for further tension with world governing body FIFA.

As a result of the dispute, the Indonesia Super League, which kicked off on April 4, was suspended after just two games, prompting FIFA to ask the minister of youth and sports to stop meddling in the running of the local football league.

entry.title: FIFA warns Indonesia govt not to meddle in domestic league

entry.title: FIFA warns Indonesia over meddling in football
entry.summary:
JAKARTA (Reuters) - Football's world governing body FIFA has written to the Indonesian government, asking the Minister of Youth and Sports to stop meddling in the running of the local football league.

A FIFA spokesperson told Reuters that if the Indonesian government did not comply with the request, FIFA could impose possible sanctions.

FIFA takes a dim view of government interference in football and a ban could prevent Indonesia from participating in the qualifying tournaments for the 2018 World Cup and 2019 Asian Cup.

The PSSI relented on Friday, saying they will halt the league, prompting FIFA's letter to the Indonesian government.

"Accordingly, FIFA requested that Indonesian authorities refrain from interfering with PSSI affairs and allow PSSI to comply with its obligations as a member of FIFA," the spokesperson said.

entry.title: FIFA report due in June on alleged South Africa match-fixing

At the top of the FIFA rankings, World Cup winners Germany remain first and Argentina second, but Belgium moved above Colombia into third after their Euro 2016 qualifying wins over Cyprus and Israel last month.

CAIRO, (Reuters) - Tarek Bouchamaoui of Tunisia and Constant Omari Selemani of the Democratic Republic of Congo were voted in on Tuesday as new members of FIFA's all-powerful executive committee to represent Africa.

The new members will serve a two-year term after which they will be up for re-election as Africa has changed its rules on how it fills its four places on the 25-man FIFA committee.

entry.title: Presidential hopeful Prince Ali demands FIFA changes
entry.summary:
CAIRO, (Reuters) - FIFA presidential candidate Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein demanded immediate change in the organisation of soccer's governing body as he issued his manifesto on Monday.

In his manifesto, entitled 'A FIFA Worthy of the World's Game', Prince Ali pledges to transform the organisation's reputation and guarantee development.

Prince Ali said FIFA's vast profits must be ploughed back into the development of the sport across the globe.

Prince Ali said FIFA had to be restored as "a proper service" group.

"We have seen that the FIFA World Cup can be a force for good," she said, "and FIFA believes this will be the case for the 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia."

entry.title: US Senators want FIFA to move 2018 World Cup out of Russia

Thirteen U.S. Senators asked FIFA to consider taking the 2018 World Cup out of Russia because of what they call that country's "ongoing violations of the territorial integrity of Ukraine."

FIFA challenger Prince Ali in Africa, Blatter's stronghold
entry.summary:
Prince Ali, a FIFA vice president and head of the Jordan Football Association, met with the president of Zimbabwe's soccer body, the sports minister and the southern African nation's vice president.

One of three men challenging Blatter for the FIFA presidency in elections in May, Prince Ali's campaign has moved to Africa ahead of the Confederation of African Football's general assembly in Cairo next week.

Blatter will attend CAF's congress as FIFA president, and will make his traditional speech.

Zimbabwe may have been a strategic place to start for Prince Ali after it was recently thrown out of 2018 World Cup qualifying by FIFA for failing to pay wages to a former national team coach.

"We want FIFA to be inclusive," Prince Ali said after his meetings, and in obvious reference to Zimbabwe's problems.

ZIFA President Cuthbert Dube, previously a Blatter supporter, said Prince Ali's visit highlighted "important issues that Zimbabwe needs more representation in FIFA and CAF so that the country benefits."

entry.title: Michel Platini Is Re-elected as UEFA President

VIENNA - Michel Platini was re-elected by acclamation as UEFA president for a third term on Tuesday and immediately told Congress delegates not to believe everything they heard about the confederation's relationship with FIFA.

Platini, whose re-election means he continues as a FIFA vice-president for the next four years, said: "Europe's entire football community loves FIFA dearly.

entry.title: Platini re-elected for third term as UEFA president

Looking at Blatter sitting in the front row, Platini said: "However, you should know we are willing to work with you, hand in hand, for the good of world football, for the good of the 209 national associations worldwide and for the good of FIFA."

"David will be the sort of person who will do the job as a FIFA executive committee member properly," English FA chairman Greg Dyke said.

"He will not be afraid of asking appropriate questions. In fact perhaps FIFA needs to have someone from the awkward squad asking tough questions.

Gill would be joining the FIFA executive committee after the May 29 presidential election.

entry.title: FIFA banks $2B in 2014; World Cup turns $337M total profit
entry.summary:
FIFA's expenses also soared, topping $5.38 billion in the past four years, including $1.955 billion in 2014.

As usual, FIFA President Sepp Blatter's salary and bonus package was not detailed in the accounts.

FIFA also paid $36 million in tax in 2014, due on its profits plus revenue earned by subsidiary companies.

FIFA said revenue tied directly to the tournament in Brazil was $4.826 billion, compared to $3.655 billion for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

The 2014 World Cup was also the most expensive to stage with total FIFA costs of $2.224 billion, including $35 million to the winning Germany federation.

FIFA says it earned record revenue of $2 billion last year, thanks to the World Cup's commercial power.

entry.title: Nepal soccer head stands down during FIFA financial probe
entry.summary:
FIFA says Nepal's top soccer official has extended his self-imposed ban while the governing body's ethics committee investigates possible financial wrongdoing.

He was an ally of former AFC President Mohamed bin Hammam, who FIFA expelled from soccer in 2012 for financial wrongdoing.

entry.title: FIFA confirms Qatar 2022 World Cup final on December 18
entry.summary: "It is a major step because finally we know and we can move forward," De Gregorio said in a statement at FIFA headquarters.

entry.title: FIFA Says 2022 World Cup Final in Qatar Will Be on Dec. 18
entry.summary:
FIFA confirmed on Thursday the date of the world's most watched sports event more than four years after it controversially chose the tiny Gulf emirate as host.

"It's a Sunday, and it's also the national day of Qatar and, yes, in principle, we try to play in 28 days," FIFA spokesman Walter De Gregorio said, confirming a decision of the executive committee in the opening session of its two-day meeting.

The announcement dominated a day FIFA hoped to dedicate to women's football.

entry.title: FIFA says 2022 World Cup final in Qatar will be on Dec. 18
entry.summary: It could be confirmed on Friday, De Gregorio said in a hastily arranged statement at FIFA headquarters.

entry.title: FIFA World Cup final to be played on Dec. 18
entry.summary:
ZURICH - The 2022 World Cup in Qatar is to be played in November and December and the final will be held on Dec. 18, FIFA spokesman Walter de Gregorio said on Thursday.

"I can confirm the executive committee today, based on the proposal of the task force...decided that, yes, we are going to play in November and December and, yes, the final is going to be played on Dec. 18," De Gregorio said at FIFA headquarters.

entry.title: FIFA says 2022 World Cup final in Qatar will be on Dec. 18
entry.summary:
FIFA President Sepp Blatter then said he preferred a Sunday, Dec. 18, final.

By rejecting UEFA's preferred Dec. 23 final, a Friday, the FIFA executive committee helped protect the English Premier League's traditional Dec. 26 program.

entry.title: Qatar 2022 World Cup final set for Dec. 18
entry.summary:
The November-December option was expected after being recommended by a FIFA-appointed task force which met last month in Doha, Qatar.

FIFA also announced it has picked France to host the Women's World Cup in 2019.

FIFA also chose France to host the Women's Under-20 World Cup in 2018, which will be played in four venues in the Brittany region.

FIFA's lowest-ranked team advances in World Cup qualifying
entry.summary: Bhutan, a Himalayan kingdom ranked 209th by FIFA, beat Sri Lanka 2-1 at home in the second leg and advanced 3-1 on aggregate.

entry.title: David Beckham welcomes Luis Figo's FIFA presidential bid
entry.summary:
LONDON (AP) - David Beckham waded into the FIFA presidential election on Tuesday, singling out former Real Madrid teammate Luis Figo in his bid to unseat Sepp Blatter.

The 39-year-old Beckham, who retired from soccer in 2013, has largely kept his distance from the world of FIFA politics after being part of England's failed 2018 World Cup bid.

"I welcome the candidacy of my friend Luis for FIFA president," Beckham said.

"FIFA will only benefit from having a wide range of strong candidates present their visions for the game and it's good to see people volunteer. I wish Luis and the other candidates well."

Figo is the only former player standing in the election, which also features FIFA vice president Prince Ali bin al-Hussein and Dutch football association chairman Michael van Praag.
